name: It’s Time to Dig Out Antique ISL
description:
Language is alive—it breathes, grows, and transforms with each generation. Indian Sign Language (ISL) is no different. But how has the ISL we know today changed from its traditional roots? What stories do these transformations tell?
Join us for a captivating panel discussion featuring three Deaf experts from across India as they unveil the fascinating journey of ISL through time. Discover how traditional sign language has evolved, what forces shaped these changes, and why understanding this evolution matters more than ever.

From historical roots to modern expressions, this conversation will reveal the cultural significance and rich heritage embedded in every gesture, while exploring how we can honor ISL's legacy in our rapidly changing world.

This event is part of the International Week of the Deaf, presented in collaboration with MAP and Hear a Million (HAM).

name: Hands-On Art: A Tactile Journey Through the MAP Collection
description:
Join Gurjeet Singh for a unique sensory journey through Visible/Invisible: Representations of Women in Art through the MAP Collection.

Designed for people with visual impairment, this tactile workshop invites participants to explore artworks through touch, then channel their experience into creating personal tactile artworks exploring ornamentation and self-expression. All workshop materials, from textile fragments to modeling tools and decorative elements, are included.

Please note: This workshop is specifically designed for people with visual disabilities. Participants are welcome to bring a friend or family member to join them.

name: Sing and Sign - Musical performance by Vasu Dixit Collective
description:
Step into a one-of-a-kind musical experience with singer–composer Vasu Dixit, and his collective as they bring a specially curated concert for deaf audiences. Blending songs in Hindi and Kannada with powerful rhythms, visuals, and emotions, this performance invites one to feel music in ways that go beyond hearing.

It’s a celebration of connection—where sound transforms into energy, movement, and shared joy. And don’t worry if you are a hearing person—this concert is designed for everyone to enjoy, experience, and listen with the heart!

name: Begin Your ISL Journey
description:
Been wanting to learn ISL but never found the time? Here’s your chance! Join us for an exciting, hands-on workshop led by deaf teachers, where you’ll dive into the world of Indian Sign Language.

Whether you’re starting with the basics, looking to play fun games, or eager to listen and share stories in ISL, this space has it all. Come learn, connect, and experience the joy of communication without barriers!

This event is part of the International Week of the Deaf, presented in collaboration with MAP and Hear a Million (HAM).

name: ISL Scavenger Hunt
description:
Join an inclusive treasure hunt where deaf and hearing participants team up to solve clues and explore the museum together. Our specially designed brochure features QR codes that unlock ISL videos, making every clue accessible and engaging for all participants.

This event is part of the International Week of the Deaf, presented in collaboration with MAP and Hear a Million (HAM).

name: Write from Art, Write from Story
description:
Explore the multifaceted world of artist and writer Ram Kumar through a unique creative writing workshop, in conjunction with our exhibition Shape of a Thought:Letters from Ram Kumar  - inviting observation, reflection, and profound emotional resonance.

This workshop draws inspiration from two powerful sources within Ram Kumar's creative universe. Participants will engage with his abstract and cityscape paintings on display, letting their emotional depth spark creative expression, while also exploring his short stories—available in translation within the gallery—with their unflinching social criticism and bold narrative voice.

Over two days, Out of Print founder and editor Indira Chandrasekhar will guide participants through exercises that deepen artistic observation and literary craft, creating a dialogue between visual and written expression.

name: In & Out of the Frame
description:
Join us for a walkthrough of our permanent exhibition with Senior Archivist from the Archives at NCBS, Anjali Ramachandran.

When we encounter artworks at a museum, we make meaning either through the work itself, its setting, or through labels that accompany them. Another way to read an artwork is to look for what's not in the 'frame'—to explore the circumstances of its creation and the use of the artwork, rather than just the artwork itself.

In this guided walk, you will get to explore our permanent exhibition, VISIBLE/INVISIBLE: Representation of Women through the MAP Collection, through the lens of an archivist. We will discuss the maker, the purpose, a specific object's relation to others, and the broader social and historical environment in which the artworks were created. In archival sciences, this is called contextualisation, where archivists understand records through the varied ways in which memories (remembered or in recorded acts) have been transmitted over time and space with numerous inscriptions, transmissions, and omissions.

Although it sounds technical, the process itself can be disruptive and playful. It involves gossip, peeking behind the curtain, and an understanding of the complex process of making art!

name: Accessible Art Experience: Tactile Walkthrough
description:
Experience art beyond sight in this special walkthrough of VISIBLE/INVISIBLE: Representation of Women in Art through the MAP Collection. Join artist Gurjeet Singh as he guides you through the tactile artworks he created specifically for this exhibition, inviting you to engage with creativity through touch and discover new dimensions of artistic expression.

This session will focus on the tactile artworks he created for the exhibition, allowing visitors to engage with art through touch and explore new ways of experiencing creativity. Gurjeet will share his inspirations, processes, and the stories behind his tactile pieces, offering audiences a unique perspective into his practice.

Joining him is MAP's Inclusion Manager, Shailesh Kulal, who will explore the accessibility measures thoughtfully integrated throughout the exhibition. From tactile guides to inclusive resources, discover why these considerations are essential for ensuring everyone can experience and enjoy art equally.

name: Deaf Theatre in the Hearing World
description:
In mainstream theatre, the stage often belongs to those who can hear. For deaf actors, opportunities are rare but that doesn’t mean their voices are silent. On the contrary, deaf performers bring a rich, visual, and deeply expressive language to the stage, challenging traditional ideas of performance and storytelling. Their work pushes us to rethink what theatre can be when sound is not the only tool for connection.

Join us for a powerful panel discussion where deaf actors, hearing directors, and industry voices come together to share their stories. Discover how they communicate, collaborate, and reimagine inclusion/access in the world of theatre.

This event is part of the International Week of the Deaf, presented in collaboration with MAP and Hear a Million (HAM).

name: ISL Jam
description:
Want to see what happens when Indian Sign Language and art come together and the magic they create? This showcase celebrates the beauty of expression beyond words, where hands, faces, and movement transform into storytelling.

Experience a vibrant line-up of performances, including Visual Vernacular, sign poetry, and innovative ISL creations from playful A-to-Z stories to rhythmic 1-to-10 storytelling and so much more. Come witness how ISL turns into art, and art turns into connection at the ISL JAM.

This event is part of the International Week of the Deaf, presented in collaboration with MAP and Hear a Million (HAM).

name: ISL for Beginners
description:
Been wanting to learn ISL but never found the time? Here’s your chance! Join us for an exciting, hands-on workshop led by deaf teachers, where you’ll dive into the world of Indian Sign Language.

Whether you’re starting with the basics, looking to play fun games, or eager to listen and share stories in ISL, this space has it all. Come learn, connect, and experience the joy of communication without barriers!

This event is part of the International Week of the Deaf, presented in collaboration with MAP and Hear a Million (HAM).

name: Make at MAP
description:
What would your dream celestial companion look like? In this edition of Make at MAP, come and create your own fantastical being, inspired by our ongoing exhibition - In Celestial Company.

Make @ MAP is a series that allows you to explore our collection in an engaging and hands-on manner. These sessions allow you to create and take home a special souvenir of your visit. It is perfect for all ages — so bring your friends and family and get ready to make some art! No experience is necessary, just a willingness to have fun and experiment with new materials.

Please note: This is a drop-in session with no registration required.

name: Y2K REWIND
Bound Together
description:
Join us for a guided walk through our digital textile exhibition, exploring how cloth serves as an expression of human creativity and cultural connection. Textiles are among the oldest human inventions, yet they remain endlessly renewed. To bind, dye, and transform cloth is a shared tradition of creativity—reminding us that making is also a way of becoming.

'Bound Together' is exhibition presents the Haveli collection (1984–2016) by designer Poornima Jain, where influences from India, Japan, and Africa were reimagined into a modern language of abstraction. The works appear in dialogue with the cultural traditions that shaped them—bandhani, leheriya, shibori, and Kuba cloths—tracing connections across geographies while celebrating the singularity of each textile.

name: Norma Rae (1979)
description:
Norma Rae©️1979 Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation. All Rights Reserved.

In collaboration with Bangalore Film Forum (BFF), MAP is excited to announce the screening of Norma Rae directed by Martin Ritt. Based on the true story of a textile worker who becomes involved in union organizing in the American South, Norma Rae is an iconic film about labour struggles. It sheds light on the harsh working conditions of mill workers and the personal cost of organizing. 

Following the screening, join us for a walkthrough of the exhibition Ticket, Tika, Chaap, which offers a deep dive into the often-overlooked world of textile labels in MAP’s collection.

Inspired by the themes of Norma Rae, we will reflect on the labour, craft, and histories embedded in these small yet powerful objects.

name: Up, Close & Centre
description: This session of Up, Close and Center looks at one of the artworks by the renowned modernist painter Ram Kumar from the exhibition Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar by curator Priya Chauhan.

name: International Week of Deaf People (IWDP) 2025
description:
In celebration of the International Week of Deaf People (IWDP) 2025, MAP is collaborating with Hear a Million to organise a series of events to promote inclusivity, awareness, and engagement with the Deaf and Hard of Hearing communities. These events are designed to highlight Deaf culture, advocate for accessibility, and foster connections between the Deaf and hearing communities through workshops, panel discussions, trivia games, scavenger hunts, musical performances and more.
IWDP 2025 EVENTS
Saturday, 27 September

- ISL Scavenger Hunt
- ISL for Beginners
- It’s Time to Dig Out Antique ISL
- Sign or Hands Down and ISL Trivia

Sunday, 28 September

- ISL Scavenger Hunt
- Begin Your ISL Journey
- Deaf Theatre in the Hearing World
- ISL Jam
- Sing and Sign – Musical performance by Vasu Dixit Collective



This year’s International Week of Deaf People celebration at MAP is supported by Adobe Foundation.

name: Sign or Hands Down and ISL Trivia
description:
Think you’ve got the quickest hands in Indian Sign Language (ISL)? Ready to put your knowledge to the test? Join us for an unforgettable event that combines fun, competition, and a whole lot of learning!

Sign or Hands Down

Four teams of two will face off in an exciting series of ISL challenges, from ISL Twisters to ISL 1-10, each round will push your quick thinking and reflexes to the limit.

Who will take home the win? The fastest thinkers and most agile signers will reign supreme!

It’s all about showing off your skills and thinking on your feet!

ISL Trivia - Kahoot!

It’s not just about speed—it’s about knowledge too! Test your ISL expertise in a fast-paced Kahoot quiz where the audience will race to answer questions and claim the top spot. Who will come out on top as the ISL trivia champion? Come join us and see it yourself.

This event is part of the International Week of the Deaf and a special collaboration between MAP and Hear a Million (HAM).
